Note: Personal protective equipment requirements are contained in Subpart I of this part. 

(Note: OSHA 29 CFR 1910 Subpart S is fundamentally a performance-based standard that defines the required level of electrical safety and protection outcomes, without prescribing a specific method for achieving them. Section 5(a)(1) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, which mandates that: 'Each employer shall furnish to each of his employees’ employment and a place of employment which are free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to his employees. While OSHA has not yet enacted a specific standard within 29 CFR 1910 governing the storage and charging of lithium-ion batteries in General Industry, the catastrophic failure of these units (thermal runaway) is a growing trend and a universally recognized hazard in the industrial sector; consequently, this hazard is enforceable under the General Duty Clause.

questions.text: Has the facility conducted an assessment of potential hazards resulting from PIT and pedestrian interactions?

references.osha:
Section 5(a)(1) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970: Each employer shall furnish to each of his employees employment and a place of employment which are free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to his employees. Employers should, therefore: Implement engineering controls, such as physical barriers (guardrails/bollards) separating walkways from vehicle lanes, designated pedestrian crosswalks, convex mirrors at blind intersections, or sensor-based collision avoidance systems reduce struck-by hazards and traffic congestion by making changes to facility layout, aisle design, and traffic flow patterns provide employees with clearly marked designated paths and high-visibility vests and train employees on how to prevent and recognize situational hazards involving mobile equipment, how to apply pedestrian right-of-way rules, and appropriate engineering controls and work practices to reduce the risk of Powered Industrial Truck (PIT) hazards.	

Note: Mere implementation of a change (e.g., painting a line on the floor) is not sufficient to satisfy an abatement requirement; the change must actually reduce the hazard. Documenting "after" assessments or traffic-flow observations provides evidence that the engineering or administrative controls implemented were effective in eliminating or reducing the recognized hazard to an acceptable level.

questions.text: Do you have adequate AEDs present at this facility?

references.osha:
Section 5(a)(1) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970: Each employer shall furnish to each of his employees employment and a place of employment which are free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to his employees. Employers should, therefore: Implement a Medical Emergency Response Plan that includes the placement of Automated External Defibrillators (AEDs) in accessible locations to address the hazard of sudden cardiac arrest ensure AEDs are available within a timeframe that optimizes survival rates (typically 3-5 minutes from collapse to shock) conduct regular maintenance and inspection of units to ensure functionality (checking pads and batteries) and provide training to designated employees on CPR and the proper use of AEDs to reduce the risk of fatality associated with medical emergencies.	

Note: Mere installation of a device (e.g., mounting a cabinet on the wall) is not sufficient to satisfy an abatement requirement; the equipment must be functional and accessible. 29 CFR 1910.1020(d)(1): Employee Medical Records: Unless a specific occupational safety and health standard provides a different period of time, each employer shall assure the preservation and retention of records as follows: The medical record for each employee shall be preserved and maintained for at least the duration of employment plus thirty (30) years, except that the following types of records need not be retained for any specified period: (A) Health insurance claims records maintained separately from the employer's medical program and its records, (B) First aid records (not including medical histories) of one-time treatment and subsequent observation of minor scratches, cuts, burns, splinters, and the like which do not involve medical treatment, loss of consciousness, restriction of work or motion, or transfer to another job, if made on-site by a non-physician and if maintained separately from the employer's medical program and its records, and (C) The medical records of employees who have worked for less than (1) year for the employer need not be retained beyond the term of employment if they are provided to the employee upon the termination of employment.

questions.text: Are there written security policies for your facility?
